pr_title: Fix updating password hash without replacing the entry

timeline.message: Fix updating password hash without replacing the entry

timeline.bodyText: Should this be part of CredentialsValidator?
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
I did consider this. Looks like InternalUsersValidator also inherits from the same and for that it is optional as some of the internal user apis are designed that way. Putting it there would make it mandatory for internal user apis.
Hence I put it in AccountValidator
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: I would prefer to remove the check especially that it is present in AccountApiAction with probably a better error message if the validation does not pass.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: This seems to consistent with the other APIs. If the mandatory keys are absent, then it throws a bad request with invalid configuration error.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: Why is it necessary to validate it twice? If you want to rely on AccountValidator, remove the check from AccountApiAction (line 217). I'd prefer the check to be done in AccountApiAction.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
If you pass
{
"password": "",
"hash": ""
}
then the validator check wont fail as the params exist.
But it fails in the account api action because they are empty/null
If you pass {} then validator check fails  as one of them is mandatory
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: OK, so AccountValidator can't even invalidate all cases.
replies.author: vrozov

timeline.bodyText: rename hash to currentHash to be consistent with currentPassword
timeline.author: vrozov
vrozov
vrozov

timeline.bodyText: Does this mean user always need to pass key "hash": "" even if user just want to pass string password or vice-versa ?
timeline.author: hardik-k-shah

replies.bodyText: No, only hash or password (or any other key present in mandatoryOrKeys). I think that the value of mandatoryOrKey is minimal as a parent or a child class can add another value to mandatoryOrKeys and the validation won't work anymore. I'd suggest to remove it.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
That is correct. One of the mandatory keys must be provided (hash or password) and other can be absent. Other APIs like role_mapping do the same.
I agree that it is not very flexible but works for this use-case.
I can remove it but code might fail at a much later stage only while comparing for hash and password.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: I suggest to remove the code and deprecate mandatoryOrKeys. It is easy to misuse and break validation accidentally. As there is already code that checks that either "password" or "hash" is present, this code is not necessary.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
This should probably be a separate issue and propose a better validation structure to use in place of this.
I do understand that this is not flexible when it comes to mandatory or keys in multiple groups eg: (f1 or f2) and (f3 or f4) but at the same time, this is not enforced.
But before we deprecate and remove this, we should have something that will

define the schema of api params instead of digging through the action code.
fail at early stage (at the beginning of processing request)
have more rigid bad request validation done here instead of in action code which is more likely to be missed (error-prone).

I strongly feel we deprecate and remove this only when we have better structure in place as this does it basic job (not saying it does the above perfectly).
If you insist I will remove this to unblock the PR but would like to hear your thoughts.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText:
I don't suggest to deprecate mandatoryOrKeys in this PR. My proposal is to avoid introducing a new dependency on it. As there is only one more RolesMappingValidator validator that depends on mandatoryOrKeys, there is not much need to make it consistent with other validators.
Later we can decide whether it is worth extending mandatoryOrKeys or not. IMO, two cases where it may be useful do not provide enough justification to make it more generic especially that there is still logic in AccountApiAction to deal with password and hash.
I do not insist, but strongly recommend to remove the dependency on mandatoryOrKeys from the AccountValidator.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
I absolutely don't mind removing it from the PR but I would like to know the following which is not clear to me:

why are we deprecating something that works?
what if the new improved solution is based out of this ?
what is the pain point of this in the use cases we have?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText:
why are we deprecating something that works?

While it works, it is fragile and is not flexible.

what if the new improved solution is based out of this?

It depends on the effort and the value the new improved solution provides. If the current functionality can be easily extended (I doubt), we may decide to extend it instead of deprecating

what is the pain point of this in the use cases we have

A duplicate check that has to be introduced anyway
replies.author: vrozov
